lines.text: May those who love us, love us. And those who don't love us - may God turn their hearts. And if He cannot turn their hearts, may he turn their ankles, so that we may know them by their limping.
I keep thinking about what you said in seminary, that the life of a priest is hard and if you can see yourself being happy doing anything else you should do that.

That was my recruitment pitch, which is not bad when you're starting out because it makes you feel like a marine. The truth is you can never tell yourself there is only one thing you could be. If you are a priest or if you marry a woman it's the same challenge. You cannot make a real commitment unless you accept that it's a choice that you keep making again and again and again.
Sometimes we don't see certain things until we're ready to see them in a certain way.
I don't doubt myself because of you. I feel like the best version of myself when I'm with you, and that makes me doubt everything else.
Let me just say... Oy.
Amen to your oy.
God was showing off when he made you.
I work harder than God. If He had hired me, He would have made the world by Thursday.
The seven deadly sins. Who can name the seven deadly sins? People! It was a very popular film with Brad Pitt, you have the ultimate cliff note.
How upset are they?
Let's just say they're less than thrilled.

[after cut to new scene]
To be honest, we're less than thrilled.
Ok, with what specifically?
With what specifically. Well, with guided meditation specifically, with stand up comedy sermons specifically, with your loose improvisational style specifically.
Ok, with people actually enjoying services? People showing up at all?
To be serenaded by the Harlem freaking gospel choir?
At least they were praying.
It was a hell of an Ein Keloheinu, Lar.
It's not kosher, Rabbi Lewis.
Larry, what does that mean?
You have to ask me what kosher means? Study your gemara.
What do you want me to do? Flagellate myself? Jews don't do that, we plant trees.
Jake Schram.
Yes.
How are you? Who are you? Tell me everything, give me the 4-1-1, I wanna know. Girls, job, news.
Now you. Anyone new in your life I should know about?
Wow, 20 minutes! I can't believe we made it this far.
It's my God-given right to check. What about the Shapiro girl.
Oh, no, not the Shapiro girl.
Why not, she was a looker.
It's not that, the problem was here.
What? Bad skin?
No, not bad skin.
What then?

Ok, you want an example? I take her out to dinner, I order dessert, she says she doesn't want any, I get pecan pie. She asks me for a bite, I give her a bite, her face swells up like a chipmunk, she looks at me and says, "Oh, my God, are there nuts in this?"
So what?
Mom! It was pecan pie.

[Brian dials Anna's phone number and hears her voice on the answering machine]
Hi, this is Anna. Only three people have this number. If you're not one of them, leave me alone.
I haven't screamed that hard since the US hockey team beat the Russians.
You think you're sorry now, wait till you realize I just went out that door and I'm not coming back.
[door slams; beat; reopens]
This is MY apartment. YOU get out.
You don't understand. I have a relationship with my phone, we have a chemistry together, I can't explain it.
So this is a rectory. That sounds like a dirty word. Rectory!
I have been a priest over 40 years, and I fell in love at least once every decade.

The truth is, I don't really learn that much about your faith by asking questions like that... because those aren't really questions about faith, those are questions about religion. And it's very important to understand the difference between religion and faith. Because faith is not about having the right answers. Faith is a feeling. Faith is a hunch, really. It's a hunch that there is something bigger connecting it all... connecting us all together. And that feeling, that hunch, is God. And coming here tonight, on your Sunday evening... to connect with that feeling, that is an act of faith. And so all I have to do is look around the room at this packed church... to know that we're doing pretty well as a community. Even if all of you failed my pop quiz miserably.
Who is the coolest woman you and I have ever known, ever.
That's easy. Anna Reilly, eighth grade. No question.
You got it.
What? She called you? Anna Reilly called you?
Yeah. Totally out of the blue.
Why?
'Cause she's coming to New York, uh, for work... and she wanted to get together with us. She just looked me up.
Really? Anna Reilly. What is she doing now?
She - She's, like, analyzing synergies, or synergising analogies, or, or some such thing. I couldn't follow it. She's, like, this very high-powered business - You know.
Woman?
Woman, yes. Thank you.
Wow. And you told her about us?
Yeah. She flipped, in a - in a good way. You know, I mean, she laughed for about ten minutes, but she was excited.
Man, that is so cool.
I know.
I wonder why she called you.
What do you mean?
No, I mean, she called you.
What, are you in the eighth grade still?
What? That's a legitimate question. I just - I mean, we're both listed.
Finn before Schram, okay? You're ridiculous.
That's a good point. Alphabetical.
Rachel Rose. Yeah. When's that going down?
Thursday.

[in Rain Man accent]
Thursday night, 8p.m., dinner.
Are you excited?
Yeah. I have a pretty good feeling.
Where are you taking her?
I don't know. I thought, uh, Ernie's.
Ernie's? You can't take her to Ernie's. Ernie's has been around since we were kids. You might as well take her to Houlihan's. You cannot take Rachel Rose to Ernie's.

[still in Rain Man accent]
Definitely not Ernie's. Definitely not. Mm-mmm. Uh-oh.
No, you gotta take her someplace new and hot.

[still in Rain Man accent]
No, hot. Definitely hot.
Well, what's - Okay, what's new and hot?
What do we know about this girl?

[still in Rain Man accent]
Rachel Rose, 29 years old, Columbia School of Journalism. Middle East affairs expert.
Perfect. Middle Eastern. She can order in Arabic. Give her a chance to shine. What's a good place?

[still in Rain Man accent]
Delphini's. Definitely Delphini's. Four stars, New York Times. Definitely Delphini's. Need a reservation. Delphini's.
Now, are you gonna wear a suit, or are you gonna go cas'?
I don't know. I don't know. I hadn't thought about it. I guess cas'.
No, suit.

[still in Rain Man accent]
Definitely suit. Definitely...
Hey, shut up, Rain Man. Seriously. Enough, all right? Now you're making me think about this.
Oh, relax. You'll do great.
I read your sarin gas report. It was very powerful.
Thanks, I really earned my stripes with that piece.
I earned my stripes by getting through a bris without fainting.
Whoa! Listen to what you're saying. You're telling me that I was supposed to be sensitive to the possibility that a Catholic priest might have a crush on my secret girlfriend?
[showing teenage Jake how to do the sign of the cross]
Spectacles, testicles, wallet, watch.
I suck! They're gonna take away my Yamulkha!
No you don't. You don't suck.
I suck.
Yes, all right, you do. You suck. But that's ok, you're supposed to suck. This isn't a talent contest, it's a rite of passage.
I just called to see how the date went.
That's so funny. I had an impulse to call you last night but then I thought it might be too late.
You should've. I was stuck here barking at Los Angeles. So what did you wear?
What? I'm not gonna tell you what I wore on my date. Why would I do that?
I want to get an image of a young rabbi on the prowl, what's your game man?
Ok. Navy blue pin stripe suit.
Mmm.
Navy blue button down shirt.
Good colour for your eyes. Shoes?
Black. Kenneth Cole. Leather.
Size?
Big.
Ow!
You wanna hear about the special knot in my tie?
Baby no, we gotta keep room for dessert. Don't give up hope ok?
I'll keep it alive.
Good bye Mr Sharp Dressed Man.
You're a Sikh, Catholic Muslim with Jewish in-laws?
Yes. Yes. It gets very complicated. I'm reading Dianetics.
Don't blame you.
Jews want their rabbis to be the kind of Jews they don't have the time to be.
Yeah, and Catholics want their priests to be the kind of Catholics they don't have the discipline to be.
What happened to our youth?
I'm telling you, it ended at 30, pal.

[to Jake]
So what's your chick situation?
Oh, don't ask, it's not a good story.
Why?
Because his whole congregation is trying to set him up and it makes him very uncomfortable.
What's wrong with that?
There's a reason pandas don't mate in captivity.
What does that mean?
It means these mothers keep making these dates for me that I can't refuse. They're very intimidating, they're like the Kosher Nostra. They're little women but very determined.
I think you get a little melodramatic about this, don't you think?
Oh, yeah? Today one of them faxed me her daughter's resume.
Let me see that. Ali Decker.
Look at the bottom.
Oh. She has a skills section.
Yes?
Oh, you win. She put jogging as a skill.
See? She doesn't even know the difference between a hobby and a skill.
All right, so maybe she's a skilled jogger.
I have to go on a date with this woman. Why can't I just say no?
I don't know, why can't you?
I can't alienate these women, I need body count at the temple.
Can I ask you a question?
Yeah, of course, anything.
It's personal, so...
Oh, are we gonna have the sex talk here?
Yes, you're my friend and I wanna know how this works for you.
Fire away, you must have a list of questions.
Really?
Really?
So you... don't. Right?
Right.
At all.
At all.
Have you ever, er?
[getting uncomfortable]
Had sex? Yes.
With women.
Yes.
So you're not gay.
No. No.
Are you sure?
Yes, but even if I was the rules are the same.
Do you miss it?
No.
Are you tempted?
Nah!
Oh, admit it. If they changed the rules you'd be psyched.
Who is calling at this hour? It's barbaric. I was dreaming about my mother's sausages.
I would like to thank you for telling me that story.
Why?
Because now I have heard it all, and I can retire.
Oh, God, please let this be painless.

[opens door]
Hi! Right on time! I like that in a rabbi!
You know you better not lie in here man, this is the big room! God does not look favorably on you. He has a tendancy to throw... lightning bolts at things... At liars!
Let me guess. Your old lady got fed up because you're out here chasing the skirt so she took these little ones and left you.
It's a little more complicated than that.
Sure it is. Everyone thinks his story is the one with a twist. Well let me tell you, I've heard just about everything there is to...
[Brian unzips his jacket, revealing his priest's collar]
Holy shit.
Exactly.
[Brian, a celibate priest, confesses his love for Anna, to Jake's astonishment]
I mean, she's like your sister!
Thank you for adding new depth to my confusion.
Oh my God! The Iraqi defense minister just committed suicide!
Ooh!... Is that bad or good?

[in an thick Philipino accent]
How you guys doing? I'm Don. Don, rhyme with flon. You have any question?
Yes, Yes indeed Don we do. Is this a good machine?
Yeah it is good if you cheap bastard. No jus... jus doing comedy with you. That one is okay. But if you are serious about Kar'-oke.
Oh we are!

Okay then... there is only one model for you. The AUDIO 2000. This baby got the 16-bit dual D/A converter, 3 beam checking, digital key controller, so you can change the pitch if your voice sucks. But I don't need that.
That's nice. How much?
Price is not important
No price is very important, actually.
Okay you got me; take me away. Okay it's a lil' bit expensive. But let me tell you, it's worth it. When you sing to your girlfriend.
Uh huh.
And her heart thweaaaatt-boom! fall down on the floor, you say thank you Don.
How much does it cost, exactly?

[Motions them over and begins to talk quietly in an American accent]
Alright, here's the real deal. Um, I don't usually do this but you guys look like cool guys, and uh, I got a little piece of ass last night, so I am feeling extra generous.
Oh!
I'm gonna let you guys have it for $1,300.
Final offer.
uh, excuse me, I just got a little warm.
[unzips jacket to reveal priest's collar]
My friend, he gets, he gets a little warm.

[Sees priest's collar]
Oh man! What is that? What is... get out of here with that. Is that real?
Oh yeah!
Don't you have work?
We're doing a hostile takeover of Congregation Bertov Sholem.
I got you something. I almost didn't because I was so mad but this is too good.
Holy shit! It's the Rabbi Schlomo Schnurson rookie card! It's like the last in the series!
God is a lot like Blanche Du Bois.
It's customary to sneak out after communion.
People should have to qualify to go out with you. You're too precious to be on the open market.
You're not gonna tell me what to do here, are you.
There's a reason you gotta do your haftorah at this age.
I thought I'd got the Tony Robbins hotline by mistake.
Rabbi Lewis! Anna, this is Rabbi Lewis.
Good to see you again Miss Riley.
Good to see you again Rabbi Lewis.
You missed our last class.
I know, I'm sorry, I thought I was leaving town.

[to Jake]
Don't look at me in that tone of voice.
I would love to start up again if that's all right with you.
I'd be delighted. Now, if you'll excuse us, we've got some dancing to do.
Tuesday's not good for me, I gotta mourn with the Schwarzes.
You write all your own sermons, right?
Actually I download them off the net, there's this great site www.hotgod.com.
Really?
[Anna kicks him under the table]
Ooh hoo, no.
I suck! They're gonna take away my Yamulkha!
No, I'm glad you saved it because it's definitely less weird for me now.
What's the story of Sodom and Gomorrah really about? Anyone? Steve Posner.
Sexual perversion.
Sexual perversion. Steve Posner's watching too much Spice Channel!
Greta Nussbaum, before she pulls her rotator cuff.

[talking about the Ein Keloheinu]
Excuse me, Raphae, guys, I just have to do this again 'cos it's really been bugging me. Ein Keloheinu. It's a joyous song, a prayer about praising the Lord, telling the Lord how much we love him, or her, but no matter what I do, I can't seem to be able to get you folks to sing it with any feeling. I mean, I brought in the band. That didn't work. I brought in my bongos last week. I think we can all agree that was a backwards step. So this morning, I've brought in a little outside help.
Whoah! Are you seriously telling me that unless you find a nice Jewish girl and settle down in the next six months they're not going to give you this job?
I'm seriously telling you there has not been a bachelor head rabbi of B'Nei Ezra since the beginning of the synagogue.
What's happening with Ruth and Ethan?
Oh. Ethan married a Catholic girl and that did not go over well.
That's why they're fighting?
They're not fighting, they're not talking. Two years now no communicado.
Are you serious?
Yeah.
What? Weren't they really close though?
As close as Ruth and Jake.
That explains a lot.
You see why tonight was not just a date.
I can't Wednesday night, I have a class.
Ok, what are these classes already?
I like to try new things sometimes, I don't wanna talk about it, I get embarrassed.
You shouldn't be embarrassed. A lot of people take... aikido.
No.
Line dancing.
Not even close.
What's the big deal, why?
Jake.
Feng Shui?
No.
You shouldn't be embarrassed if it's Feng Shui. You know what? Don't tell me, I like the whole mysterioso thing, it turns me on.
I'm gonna miss a lot of things around here. Like Len's endless Howard Stern recountings and of course my Romeo Casanova boy across the way.

[someone in Casanova's office starts waving a sign]
Hey, what is that?
I don't know.
[looks through binoculars]
Who is that?
It's Jake.
What's he doing?

[He's miming "pick up the phone", she picks up the phone]
Anna Riley.
Hi, Anna? Can, can you see me? Cause I can't see you, I'm just looking at a reflection of myself.
Jake, I can see you, what are you doing?

I've been trying to get up there for the last hour but it's like the frigging Pentagon with that T-Bone guy. So I decided to try Mr Casanova here - by the way his name is Howard. Anyway I've been doing some thinking and there are some things I'd like to talk to you about.
[Debbie switches to speakerphone]
Am I on speakerphone?
Hi, Jake!
Hi. Hi. Can I talk to you alone? Can I come over there?
No, I think now would be a good time.
Ok. Well, I've been thinking about some of the things you said and you were right.
About what?
About us. About me, especially about me.
So what are you saying Jake?
Yeah, what are you saying Jake?
I'm saying I love you. I'm in love with you. And I've been waiting my whole life for someone like you and I'm not gonna let you go. Please don't go. Anna, I'm not gonna let you go.
[pause]
Could we hang up the phone maybe.
Is it me or is confession getting a little touchy-feely these days?
If I was to tell you that I loved you and I'd give it all away just to be with you, what would you say?
Good night, Paulie.
Yep. That's about par for the evening.

[to Anna]
Excuse me if I say that I don't think I'm the best person to offer objective advice on this particular confession.
Feel the prana!
Well, looks like I'm going to Baghdad.
We have a chemistry together, I can't explain it.
Well, chemistry's a funny thing.
Yes, it is. Are you speaking abstractly or specifically?
Abstractly.
Holy majoly!
He's, like, porn slapping her!
You're gonna benefit from this!

[to Brian and Anna]
So how long have you two been together?
Oh, right!
Oh, we go way back.
Yeah, we've known each other since we were kids 'cause we grew up together and we connected again a couple months back this was and we just clicked, really unexpectedly.

I remember I fell in love with this girl in Prague. She was beautiful. She looked like Carol Lombard. She grabbed me in the alley behind my church, she pressed me up against the wall, she kissed me. I was so happy I thought I would die, I felt like Richard Chamberlain in "The Thorn Birds", you know with Meggie in the attic.
You never told me this. Did anything happen between you?
Not really. Flirtations, little moments, but soon after the Russians invaded Czechoslovakia and I moved to the United States.
He has a healthy self-confidence, I can tell from his posturing.
I've seen the way women look at you, even though they know you're a priest - especially when they know actually.
You wanna bring a priest to your first good date in two years? What kind of strategy is that?
You look so hot in your suit, can I just tell you.
Thank you. You look beautiful.
Yeah, you really do.
Thanks, men!
I don't know what it is.
An absence of something.
Yeah, the cell phone.
Uh, uh, uh. It's set to vibrate.
Wow, that's... sexy.
You must think I'm such an idiot!
No, Brian!
No, no no, I think I'm an idiot!
I'm Irish! This is milk to me baby! Milk!
I feel like I'm on some bad new Aaron Spelling show - "Melrose Priest."
You're in love with her?

[to himself]
No one seems to have picked up on this. It's very strange.

[speaking passionately in Spanish to Father Brian inside a confessional]
Mrs. Lopez, she's seriously hot, she's got a rack like
[gestures with his hands]
... Forgive Father...

[in Spanish]
Really, don't worry about it. It's completely normal to have those feelings, everyone has them. What's important is what you do with those feelings. Understand?
Sí.
Sí?
Mmmhmm.
I don't do penance, I do shots.

[Omar bumps into Brian and Anna]
Omar!

[in Spanish]
Sorry, father, hey she has a nice ass!

[in Spanish]
You're the expert, huh?
I'm God's consiglieri.
What could possibly be holding you back at this point?

[voiceover]
My parents had basically given up on children when I came along, so my mother always called me her 'gift from God.' That really stuck with me and when I was eight I told her I had a feeling I was supposed to return the favor. She was so happy she cried. My dad just wanted to know if working for God came with dental.
Um, let me get this straight. I am talking to a pries who went on a bender because his best friend, a rabbi, stole his girl.
Right.
Thank you. I want to thank you for telling me this story.
Why?
Because now I can retire.
So? She's a woman, she's not the Virgin Mary!
[punched]
How is that possible?
